awd_titl_txt: Structural controls on Fe oxide formation: A crystallographic analysis of the growth of hematite versus goethite
awd_abstract_narration:
Dating back to the earliest hominids, the minerals hematite and goethite (both iron oxides) have provided us with durable, non-toxic red, yellow, and brown pigments, and today these minerals are synthesized in the millions of tons.  They also are of critical economic importance because they serve as the primary reserves used to extract iron, and iron accounts for 90% of the world's metal consumption.  Moreover, they can control the ability of soils to remove contaminants from groundwater because they frequently form as coatings on other soil minerals, such as quartz and feldspar. Even as only a microscopic veneer, they can attract and remove toxic metals, which otherwise would not react with the quartz or feldspar hosts.  In spite of their economic and environmental significance, geologists continue to debate how they form and what mechanism determines which of either hematite or goethite is likely to crystallize. Understanding this formation process matters because some scientists have used hematite and goethite ratios to infer the climatic conditions that generated ancient soils.  This project strives to determine the chemical conditions that dictate whether hematite or goethite will form in natural environments by using an innovative X-ray scattering technique that allows researchers to monitor iron oxide minerals at the atomic scale as they crystallize from fluids. In addition to this research helping scientists design more accurate historical (and predictive) climate models, the Investigators will also develop an interactive program that focuses on the geological and technological significance of iron oxides. These exercises will take advantage of a Smithsonian Learning Center called Q?rius, which attracts approximately 100,000 school children each year, and the U.S. National Museum of Natural History's extensive collection of iron oxide specimens to explain the important role of these minerals for maintaining the nation's technological and economic welfare.

Over the past decade, several studies have argued that the ratio of hematite to goethite in soils can yield quantitative estimates of mean annual precipitation, raising the possibility that hematite/goethite ratios in paleosols may serve as proxies for ancient climate.  The application of hematite/goethite proxies to Ordovician paleosols has, however, conflicted with the results of well-established climatic indicators.  Recent research by the Principal Investigators has revealed that the crystallization of hematite relative to goethite is determined by a complex interplay of solution pH, temperature, and time.  The PIs hypothesize that the formation of goethite is outcompeted in certain conditions by the metastability of 'hydrohematite,' a mineral discovered 175 years ago and discredited in the 1920s.  Specifically, they suggest that the reaction of ferrihydrite to hydrohematite is favored in alkaline systems (pH ~8) at low to moderate temperatures (below 130oC).  The composition of hydrohematite falls halfway between those of the goethite and hematite endmembers, and the transition from hydrohematite to stoichiometric hematite involves structural discontinuities suggestive of the onset of magnetic coupling between neighboring iron atoms.  The PIs will combine state-of-the-art, synchrotron X-ray diffraction techniques with computational methods to understand the factors that control the relative thermodynamic stabilities in this system of iron (hydr)oxide nanophases.  Accurate applications of hematite/goethite proxies for paleoclimate reconstruction require a rigorous understanding of the rates at which ferrihydrite alters to goethite and hematite and on the variables that influence which reaction products form.  The series of research thrusts outlined in this proposal will provide important constraints on the character and the rates by which iron (hydr)oxides evolve in maturing soils.  The results thus will improve the utility of hematite and goethite as a climate indicator, and they will reveal the relationship between the defect states and the physical properties and behaviors of iron oxides.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Iron is the fourth most abundant element in the Earth's crust by weight percent (and sixth by atom percent), and of the ten most common crustal elements, it is the only one that naturally exists in multiple oxidation states.  The mineral hematite (Fe2O3) is known to be the energetically stable variety of iron oxide in all moderately and strongly oxidizing environments, and hematite is the most abundant and important of the iron ore minerals.  Iron still accounts for >90% of all metals consumed annually. Thus, even though our technological age has evolved to one based on silicon and rare-earth elements rather than iron, iron remains vital to the everyday functioning of modern civilization.

In light of its ubiquity, its economic importance, and its apparent chemical simplicity, it is curious that the genesis of hematite in sedimentary systems remains the subject of heated debate.  Hematite occurs widely as coatings on detrital grains in sedimentary red beds and "terra rossa" soils, particularly within heavily weathered deposits.  The hematite within these coatings typically is nanocrystalline, and often it is intimately intergrown with other poorly crystalline hydroxides, such as goethite (FeOOH) and aluminosilicate clays.  The formation of these iron hydroxide coatings in soils and sediments is of strong environmental interest: 

1) The large surface areas and adsorptive capacities of nanoparticulate iron hydroxides promote the sequestration of toxic metals from polluted groundwaters by soils and porous rocks;

 2) The relative abundances and varieties of iron oxides in soils and sedimentary rocks have been cited as proxies for climate, particularly mean annual precipitation. The robustness of these proxies is questionable when the mechanisms of iron hydroxide growth, transformation, and dissolution are so poorly constrained.

NSF grant EAR1925903 has supported 14 peer-reviewed publications from our group. Some of the major results from this research follow:

1) Ratios of hematite to goethite in sedimentary rocks are used for paleoclimate reconstruction, but the parameters that control the relative quantities of these minerals are still not well calibrated.  Our manuscript entitled "Hematite-goethite ratios at pH 2-13 and 25-170 oC: A time-resolved synchrotron X-ray diffraction study" was published in Chemical Geology in 2022.  This work demonstrates for the first time that goethite and hematite grow simultaneously during the transformation from ferrihydrite, but the ratios change during particle growth until plateauing at values determined by pH, temperature, and activity of H2O.

2) Our manuscript entitled "Vacancy infilling during the crystallization of Fe-deficient hematite: An in situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction study of non-classical crystal growth" explores the transformation of ferrihydrite to hematite at pH 10 and 11 over temperatures of 80 to 170 oC.  Our analysis revealed that incipient hematite crystals are "missing" iron. Vacancies in the crystal structure are filled as the nanoparticles increase in size, but the infilling is strongly constrained by pH and temperature. We can use our measurements of missing iron to make inferences about the chemistry and maturity of the solutions that formed the iron oxides.    

3) By examining hydrous hematite specimens from historical museum collections in Freiberg, Germany, the Smithsonian, and the Penn State Genth collection, we demonstrated the reality of hydrohematite, a mineral whose composition lies halfway between those of goethite and hematite. Hydrohematite was proposed as a new mineral in the 1840s and discredited in the 1920s.  This study also demonstrated the natural existence of "hydrogoethite", a superhydrous variety of goethite.

4) Despite the closure of the Advanced Photon Source for in-person experiments from spring 2020 to early fall 2022, we performed remote experiments involving high-temperature transformations of iron, manganese and titanium oxides.  Our analyses of pyrolusite (MnO2) and rutile (TiO2) during heating have provided the highest resolution coefficients of thermal expansion to date, and they show solid-state evidence for Mn reduction and O2 generation prior to the transformations of pyrolusite to bixbyite and hausmannite. 

5) Heaney and Post have collaborated with former graduate student Dr. Florence Ling (associate professor at La Salle University) and former postdoctoral researcher Dr. Margaret Anne Hinkle (assistant professor at Washington and Lee University) to characterize metal oxide precipitation at a passive remediation system for acid mine waste in central PA. Run-off from this abandoned coal mine has extremely high Fe and Mn concentrations, and we have collaborated with a local company called EcoIslands to explore the effectiveness of metal removal units with coconut coir and multiple treatment beds lined with dolomitic cobble. Recent research by Post and Heaney has revealed that Raman spectroscopy is highly sensitive to the symmetry and Mn oxidation state of birnessite-like minerals, and we employed Raman alongside SEM, TEM, synchrotron EXAFS, and XRD to characterize the minerals precipitated in the treatment system.
